36fc813a-7663-4efe-a2e5-86e0170ebe4d.label: Positive Vertical Shift
36fc813a-7663-4efe-a2e5-86e0170ebe4d.description: Adding a positive constant 'k' to f(x) moves the graph upward by 'k' units. All y-values increase, affecting the range.
examples: The graph of f(x) = sin(x) + 2 is sin(x) shifted up 2 units.

c1e44b2f-a292-46d1-a54f-8a8bf2cb6636.label: Negative Vertical Shift
c1e44b2f-a292-46d1-a54f-8a8bf2cb6636.description: Adding a negative constant (subtracting 'k') from f(x) moves the graph downward by 'k' units. All y-values decrease, affecting the range.
examples: The graph of f(x) = cos(x) - 1 is cos(x) shifted down 1 unit.

2cbc0564-01cb-4885-8c11-27d996787596.label: Vertical Shifts: Adding to the Output
2cbc0564-01cb-4885-8c11-27d996787596.description: Adding a constant 'k' to a function, f(x) + k, shifts the entire graph vertically.  Positive 'k' moves the graph up, while negative 'k' moves it down. This affects the range.
examples: f(x) = x^2 + 5 shifts the standard parabola up 5 units
If f(x) has a max at (2,4), f(x)+3 has a max at (2,7)

b69a9bcc-86dc-4b2e-b267-fff26e4ec0e5.label: Positive Horizontal Shift
b69a9bcc-86dc-4b2e-b267-fff26e4ec0e5.description: Adding a positive constant 'h' to 'x' inside f(x) shifts the graph left by 'h' units.  The x-values decrease.
examples: f(x) = sqrt(x+1) shifts the square root graph left 1 unit.
f(x)=(x+5)^2 shifts the parabola left 5 units

3bb207c9-e811-4660-adeb-c1d15bd569ad.label: Negative Horizontal Shift
3bb207c9-e811-4660-adeb-c1d15bd569ad.description: Subtracting a constant 'h' from 'x' inside f(x) shifts the graph right by 'h' units. The x-values increase.
examples: f(x) = 1/(x-2) shifts the reciprocal graph right 2 units.
f(x)=|x-3| shifts the absolute value graph right 3 units

69f70348-4c16-4074-a251-cfe5e8b8cd3c.label: Horizontal Shifts: Adding to the Input
69f70348-4c16-4074-a251-cfe5e8b8cd3c.description: Adding a constant 'h' inside the function, f(x + h), shifts the graph horizontally. Positive 'h' shifts left, negative 'h' shifts right, impacting the domain.
examples: f(x) = (x - 2)^2 shifts the standard parabola right 2 units
If f(x) has a zero at (1,0), f(x-4) has a zero at (5,0)

e35a1b47-7c3b-4590-9c52-5f8270fa13e6.label: Combined Vertical and Horizontal Shifts
e35a1b47-7c3b-4590-9c52-5f8270fa13e6.description: Combining both shifts results in f(x + h) + k, where 'h' is the horizontal shift and 'k' is the vertical shift.  Order doesn't matter.

a832a806-3b45-495a-9719-1a37cc025d91.label: Vertical and Horizontal Shifts of Functions
a832a806-3b45-495a-9719-1a37cc025d91.description: Functions can be translated vertically or horizontally by adding or subtracting constants to the output or input, respectively. These shifts alter the graph's position without changing its shape.
examples: f(x) + 2 shifts the graph of f(x) up by 2
f(x - 3) shifts the graph of f(x) right by 3

723e7b5a-ded6-4b6e-88ef-14b3c1fa492e.label: Vertical Reflection: Across the x-axis
723e7b5a-ded6-4b6e-88ef-14b3c1fa492e.description: Multiplying the function by -1, -f(x), reflects the graph vertically across the x-axis. The y-values change sign.
examples: f(x) = -sin(x) reflects the sine function across the x-axis

bfaeb1c0-ab4a-42c5-9014-2911b591c32a.label: Horizontal Reflection: Across the y-axis
bfaeb1c0-ab4a-42c5-9014-2911b591c32a.description: Replacing 'x' with '-x', f(-x), reflects the graph horizontally across the y-axis. The x-values change sign.
examples: f(x) = sqrt(-x) reflects the square root function across the y-axis
f(x) = (-x)^3 reflects the cubic function across the y-axis

78703f9c-7549-409b-94de-bf5f21c9ad18.label: Even and Odd Functions Symmetry
78703f9c-7549-409b-94de-bf5f21c9ad18.description: Even functions are symmetric about the y-axis (f(-x) = f(x)), while odd functions are symmetric about the origin (f(-x) = -f(x)).

f5062129-9d5c-49c8-a01f-7d3b8dfae2c5.label: Reflections about the Axes
f5062129-9d5c-49c8-a01f-7d3b8dfae2c5.description: Reflections create a mirror image of the function across the x-axis or y-axis. These transformations change the sign of either the output or the input.

0ffbfd3c-6d29-41d5-b9e7-b3946a15f214.label: Vertical Stretches and Compressions
0ffbfd3c-6d29-41d5-b9e7-b3946a15f214.description: Multiplying the function by a constant 'a', a*f(x), vertically stretches (a > 1) or compresses (0 < a < 1) the graph.
examples: 2x^2: Vertical stretch of x^2 by factor 2

9ea33508-9b91-4106-ad44-fd987863f3d6.label: Horizontal Stretches and Compressions
9ea33508-9b91-4106-ad44-fd987863f3d6.description: Multiplying the input by a constant 'b', f(b*x), horizontally compresses (b > 1) or stretches (0 < b < 1) the graph.  Note the reciprocal effect.
examples: sqrt(2x): Horizontal compression of sqrt(x) by factor 2
(0.5x)^3: Horizontal stretch of x^3 by factor 2

267ba918-9bad-4176-ad8f-7741d41589d8.label: Stretches and Compressions of Functions
267ba918-9bad-4176-ad8f-7741d41589d8.description: These transformations alter the shape of the graph by either stretching it away from or compressing it toward an axis.  They involve multiplying the function or its argument by a constant.
examples: 2*f(x) vertically stretches the graph of f(x)
f(0.5*x) horizontally stretches the graph of f(x)

ad4734bd-4dbe-4803-90f4-5fd97e928a56.label: Combining Multiple Transformations
ad4734bd-4dbe-4803-90f4-5fd97e928a56.description: Multiple transformations can be combined, but the order matters.  Horizontal and vertical transformations are independent. Factoring the 'inside' is key.
examples: 2(x-1)^2 + 3: Shift right 1, vertical stretch 2, shift up 3
sqrt(0.5x + 1) - 2: Horizontal stretch 2, shift left 2, shift down 2

9c215bc1-682f-46d4-93d5-252559941213.label: Transformations of Functions: Shifts, Reflections, Stretches, Compressions
9c215bc1-682f-46d4-93d5-252559941213.description: This section explores how to modify function graphs through shifts, reflections, stretches, and compressions.  Understanding these transformations allows us to model real-world phenomena effectively and manipulate functions to fit specific needs.
examples: Shifting a parabola up by 2 units
Reflecting a sine wave across the x-axis

abc13ecd-03a2-4d57-b043-f387f9a651de.label: Coefficient's Impact
abc13ecd-03a2-4d57-b043-f387f9a651de.description: The coefficient 'k' scales the power function vertically. Positive 'k' means the graph lies above the x-axis for positive x.

f4c358ad-d153-4187-8964-acae251e887b.label: Exponent's Influence
f4c358ad-d153-4187-8964-acae251e887b.description: The exponent 'p' determines the shape and end behavior of the power function. Integer and non-integer exponents lead to different graph characteristics.
examples: p=1/2 creates a square root function

2d8dd2e0-e415-4cad-9baf-b3ea2898f7f9.label: Defining Power Functions: General Form
2d8dd2e0-e415-4cad-9baf-b3ea2898f7f9.description: A power function is expressed as f(x) = kx^p, where k is a real number coefficient and p is any real number exponent. Understanding the roles of k and p.

fe066cec-d2ef-46fe-9c64-ebbfc175ca87.label: Even Power End Behavior
fe066cec-d2ef-46fe-9c64-ebbfc175ca87.description: For even powers, as x approaches positive or negative infinity, f(x) approaches positive infinity. The graph is symmetric about the y-axis.

36067516-14de-48ce-bc6a-a8d173cba733.label: Odd Power End Behavior
36067516-14de-48ce-bc6a-a8d173cba733.description: For odd powers, as x approaches positive infinity, f(x) approaches positive infinity; as x approaches negative infinity, f(x) approaches negative infinity.

519e003a-745f-461a-aad2-26d05a549435.label: End Behavior: Even and Odd Powers
519e003a-745f-461a-aad2-26d05a549435.description: Analyzing how power functions behave as x approaches positive or negative infinity, based on whether the exponent is even or odd.
examples: x^2 goes to infinity as x goes to +/- infinity
x^3 goes to infinity as x goes to infinity, -infinity as x goes to -infinity

86b8cf92-9a43-4c80-a99f-b832eab5c239.label: Power Functions: Definition and Behavior
86b8cf92-9a43-4c80-a99f-b832eab5c239.description: Understanding power functions, their general form, end behavior, and how they differ based on the exponent being an integer or a non-integer value.

5aef37aa-e43e-4861-a7ec-edd2ff8263c3.label: Defining Polynomial Functions: General Form
5aef37aa-e43e-4861-a7ec-edd2ff8263c3.description: A polynomial function is the sum of terms, each term being a real number coefficient multiplied by x raised to a non-negative integer power.

1e68a4ae-aeda-4dff-8d59-5b0c97bc58a6.label: Degree and Leading Coefficient: Key Features
1e68a4ae-aeda-4dff-8d59-5b0c97bc58a6.description: The degree is the highest power of x in the polynomial. The leading coefficient is the coefficient of the term with the highest power.
examples: Degree of 3x^4 + ... is 4, leading coefficient is 3
Degree of x^5 + ... is 5, leading coefficient is 1

84b5d3d8-3e73-4ca9-9811-15ce8dc01e4a.label: Impact of Degree and Leading Coefficient
84b5d3d8-3e73-4ca9-9811-15ce8dc01e4a.description: The degree and leading coefficient impact the overall shape and end behavior of the polynomial function's graph. They are crucial for analysis.
examples: Even degree, positive LC: ends up on both sides
Odd degree, negative LC: ends down, right down

4c3cd32a-bb41-4f7d-9b8f-b83628d644aa.label: Polynomial Functions: Structure and Properties
4c3cd32a-bb41-4f7d-9b8f-b83628d644aa.description: Defining polynomial functions, identifying their degree and leading coefficient, and understanding how these features influence their graphs.

421a58ed-3d16-48ea-b6d4-7bcd8cbf5c22.label: Online Resources for Further Learning
421a58ed-3d16-48ea-b6d4-7bcd8cbf5c22.description: Links to external websites with additional explanations, examples, and interactive tools for understanding power and polynomial functions.

36f48acd-0422-4bf4-8827-d04aa58abc41.label: Section Exercises for Practice
36f48acd-0422-4bf4-8827-d04aa58abc41.description: Working through exercises to solidify understanding of the concepts and techniques related to power and polynomial functions.

ec8cd3ee-7164-4315-ab6b-4f3220c1c10b.label: Additional Resources and Exercises
ec8cd3ee-7164-4315-ab6b-4f3220c1c10b.description: Accessing online resources and working through exercises for further instruction and practice with power and polynomial functions.

b009ca5d-98fd-448b-a10b-9a2d2f92e686.label: Power and Polynomial Functions Overview
b009ca5d-98fd-448b-a10b-9a2d2f92e686.description: Exploration of power functions, polynomial functions, their graphs, end behavior, zeros, division, rational functions, inverses, radical functions, and modeling with variation.

fa06d0c2-9b61-48b5-8857-dae4d0f491ac.label: Positive Base Requirement
fa06d0c2-9b61-48b5-8857-dae4d0f491ac.description: The base 'b' must be positive to ensure real number outputs, avoiding imaginary results with fractional exponents.

c89f53d5-c567-441c-808b-c0a927d7a6cd.label: Base Not Equal to One
c89f53d5-c567-441c-808b-c0a927d7a6cd.description: The base 'b' cannot be 1, as it would result in a constant function, not exponential growth or decay.

aaabf857-7a5e-41a7-bcfb-3ee6edb78501.label: General Form and Base Restrictions
aaabf857-7a5e-41a7-bcfb-3ee6edb78501.description: Defining the general form f(x) = a * b^x, with 'a' as the initial value and 'b' as the base (b > 0, b != 1).
examples: Why b cannot be negative or 1

dbd993e2-1e0b-434a-ac7a-b9b396e26dea.label: Horizontal Asymptote
dbd993e2-1e0b-434a-ac7a-b9b396e26dea.description: Exponential functions have a horizontal asymptote at y = 0, which the graph approaches but never crosses.

bb069782-6179-4a1c-ac58-22efdd5d4350.label: Y-Intercept
bb069782-6179-4a1c-ac58-22efdd5d4350.description: The y-intercept of an exponential function is (0, a), where 'a' is the initial value.
examples: The graph crosses y-axis at (0, a)

572a7a26-b029-4a17-b378-fdcdfadfdd6d.label: Domain and Range
572a7a26-b029-4a17-b378-fdcdfadfdd6d.description: The domain of an exponential function is all real numbers, while the range is positive real numbers (or negative if 'a' is negative).

fd3eb222-40dc-4f0d-9671-9b9fa35caee3.label: Growth Factor
fd3eb222-40dc-4f0d-9671-9b9fa35caee3.description: When b > 1, the function represents exponential growth, with the output increasing as the input increases.

1fc96885-b7ae-4c27-a42a-12c40a9e55be.label: Decay Factor
1fc96885-b7ae-4c27-a42a-12c40a9e55be.description: When 0 < b < 1, the function represents exponential decay, with the output decreasing as the input increases.

3d7564ca-e7e2-4aa4-b7ad-29022cf834fc.label: Exponential Growth vs. Decay
3d7564ca-e7e2-4aa4-b7ad-29022cf834fc.description: Distinguishing between exponential growth (b > 1) and exponential decay (0 < b < 1) based on the base value.

0103aa52-6a40-4d24-8faa-7271025fbaff.label: Defining Exponential Functions
0103aa52-6a40-4d24-8faa-7271025fbaff.description: Understanding the core characteristics and mathematical definition of exponential functions, differentiating them from linear and power functions.

448d8559-2c39-4316-9339-29b91db28bae.label: Parentheses
448d8559-2c39-4316-9339-29b91db28bae.description: Parentheses first, then exponents, multiplication, division, addition, subtraction

9e06a3e8-be0e-473a-a65e-72358462abdd.label: Order of Operations
9e06a3e8-be0e-473a-a65e-72358462abdd.description: Emphasizing the importance of following the order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS) when evaluating exponential expressions.

2d861522-eb4b-4afc-8f61-5855656b22ff.label: Rounding
2d861522-eb4b-4afc-8f61-5855656b22ff.description: Rounding the final answer to a specified number of decimal places for accuracy.

c081da5d-f1a2-4ee6-ad5e-3dae9478e971.label: Calculator Usage
c081da5d-f1a2-4ee6-ad5e-3dae9478e971.description: Using a calculator to evaluate exponential functions, especially for non-integer exponents or large numbers.

bd41f2aa-ad2d-4fbf-825d-9382e4d7b710.label: Evaluating Exponential Functions
bd41f2aa-ad2d-4fbf-825d-9382e4d7b710.description: Methods for evaluating exponential functions for given inputs, including order of operations and calculator usage.

8d75834f-c167-477b-98a7-7498b25104f5.label: Solving for 'a'
8d75834f-c167-477b-98a7-7498b25104f5.description: Substituting the first point into the general form and isolating 'a' to express it in terms of 'b'.

60d66719-cb68-4539-8fac-5c988f26655f.label: Solving for 'b'
60d66719-cb68-4539-8fac-5c988f26655f.description: Substituting the expression for 'a' into the second equation and solving for 'b'.

576f2c29-f2a2-48e9-9871-fed2edc430dc.label: Using Two Data Points
576f2c29-f2a2-48e9-9871-fed2edc430dc.description: Solving a system of two equations to find 'a' and 'b' when given two data points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2).
examples: Substituting points into y = a * b^x

7cd48e26-f6a5-4742-82a3-c84e485f28b3.label: Substituting Second Point
7cd48e26-f6a5-4742-82a3-c84e485f28b3.description: Substituting the second data point into the equation y = a * b^x (with known 'a') and solving for 'b'.

adfd6179-a5db-4ca4-8e95-2b338e0d6df4.label: Using Initial Value
adfd6179-a5db-4ca4-8e95-2b338e0d6df4.description: If the y-intercept (0, a) is known, 'a' is the initial value, simplifying the process of finding the equation.
examples: Substituting (x, y) and a into y = a * b^x

bfb9ca45-dc44-4752-bead-fd0bfb316668.label: Data Input
bfb9ca45-dc44-4752-bead-fd0bfb316668.description: Entering the x and y coordinates of the given points into the L1 and L2 lists on the calculator.

087d51ba-cd7e-4129-a0c9-d053d80b17a0.label: Exponential Regression
087d51ba-cd7e-4129-a0c9-d053d80b17a0.description: Using the exponential regression function (ExpReg) to calculate the values of 'a' and 'b' for the exponential equation.
examples: Selecting ExpReg from the CALC menu
Reading the a and b values from the display

ed164eba-b3ed-4c55-a73f-311dac147fcf.label: Graphing Calculator Method
ed164eba-b3ed-4c55-a73f-311dac147fcf.description: Using statistical functions on a graphing calculator to perform exponential regression and find the equation.
examples: Inputting data into L1 and L2

246abdd9-780f-4053-a472-0cdc2c845272.label: Finding Equations of Exponential Functions
246abdd9-780f-4053-a472-0cdc2c845272.description: Determining the equation of an exponential function given data points or its graph, including solving for initial value and base.
examples: Using two points to solve for a and b

c96ac689-455f-47db-8620-357ecf35d08c.label: APR Conversion
c96ac689-455f-47db-8620-357ecf35d08c.description: Converting the annual percentage rate (APR) from a percentage to a decimal by dividing by 100.

d26733a5-9b93-430d-b22f-2f5dc97672b7.label: Understanding Variables
d26733a5-9b93-430d-b22f-2f5dc97672b7.description: Defining each variable in the compound interest formula: A (account value), t (time), P (principal), r (APR), and n (compounding periods).

b4964d55-75a5-4630-a88a-9d532125df44.label: Effective Interest Rate
b4964d55-75a5-4630-a88a-9d532125df44.description: The actual interest rate earned due to compounding, which is higher than the nominal APR.

9c66c850-be65-4af1-9993-f0d482f3266b.label: Compounding Frequency
9c66c850-be65-4af1-9993-f0d482f3266b.description: Understanding the impact of compounding frequency (n) on the future value of the investment.

23dd0647-b839-449a-8695-44914159ca17.label: Applying Compound Interest Formula
23dd0647-b839-449a-8695-44914159ca17.description: Using the compound interest formula to calculate the future value of an investment with periodic compounding.
examples: Using the formula A = P(1 + r/n)^(nt)

b0844c01-1271-4e99-affa-ca46248501fc.label: Exponential Functions: Definition, Properties, and Applications
b0844c01-1271-4e99-affa-ca46248501fc.description: Exploration of exponential functions, covering their definition, evaluation, equation formation, and applications in compound interest and real-world modeling. Includes growth and decay.

7d800a4f-5037-485c-a455-950ae9dacb99.label: Naming a Ray
7d800a4f-5037-485c-a455-950ae9dacb99.description: A ray is named using its endpoint and any other point on the ray, e.g., ray EF or symbolized as EF.
examples: Naming a ray using two points on the line

a1777b12-185d-46e8-97e2-04cdf83657fa.label: Ray Definition and Endpoint
a1777b12-185d-46e8-97e2-04cdf83657fa.description: A ray is part of a line extending infinitely in one direction from a specific endpoint. Named using the endpoint and another point.
examples: Ray AB starts at point A and extends through point B
Representing a ray with symbolic notation

0014a149-5b65-45eb-84f0-3b73ea3f178c.label: Naming Angles
0014a149-5b65-45eb-84f0-3b73ea3f178c.description: Angles are named using points on each ray and the vertex (e.g., angle DEF or ∠DEF) or with Greek letters (e.g., θ, α).
examples: Using three points to name an angle
Using a Greek letter to represent an angle

a7605c9c-e7c0-4af9-b91c-58e05c876f07.label: Dynamic Angle Creation
a7605c9c-e7c0-4af9-b91c-58e05c876f07.description: One ray is fixed (initial side), and the other rotates (terminal side). Direction of rotation indicates positive or negative angle.
examples: Visualizing counterclockwise rotation for a positive angle
Visualizing clockwise rotation for a negative angle

7358bcc4-6431-4949-96f4-af01ff8082be.label: Angle Formation and Vertex
7358bcc4-6431-4949-96f4-af01ff8082be.description: An angle is formed by the union of two rays sharing a common endpoint, called the vertex. Sides are the forming rays.
examples: Angle DEF formed by rays DE and EF with vertex at E
Identifying the vertex and sides of an angle

e09df880-1108-4969-8bd1-836eb5eb2692.label: Axis Alignment
e09df880-1108-4969-8bd1-836eb5eb2692.description: Terminal side of quadrantal angles align with x or y axis.
examples: 90 degree angle terminal side on positive y axis
180 degree angle terminal side on negative x axis

abde0087-28b8-416a-85b7-5ad2d412b2bf.label: Quadrantal Angles
abde0087-28b8-416a-85b7-5ad2d412b2bf.description: Angles in standard position whose terminal side lies on an axis: 0°, 90°, 180°, 270°, 360°.
examples: Identifying 90° angle as a quadrantal angle

03b7f397-55ab-4744-b82d-c55bf9e5548a.label: Angles in Standard Position
03b7f397-55ab-4744-b82d-c55bf9e5548a.description: Defining angles within a coordinate plane with vertex at origin and initial side along the positive x-axis, and understanding positive/negative angles.
examples: Drawing 30° angle with initial side on positive x-axis

4d69b984-9a7f-4099-961a-9ae5ca0bfc3a.label: Degree Notation
4d69b984-9a7f-4099-961a-9ae5ca0bfc3a.description: Angles measured in degrees always include the unit "degrees" or the degree symbol (°).
examples: Expressing 90 degrees with the degree symbol

aaaca7ca-9c54-4a99-a4ec-bc85a3f98372.label: Degree Definition
aaaca7ca-9c54-4a99-a4ec-bc85a3f98372.description: One degree (1°) is 1/360 of a full circular rotation. A complete rotation is 360 degrees.

7936ac9e-559b-4fdd-9be7-59961c118624.label: Full Circle in Radians
7936ac9e-559b-4fdd-9be7-59961c118624.description: A full circle (360°) is equal to 2π radians. This is the basis for degree-radian conversion.

f0341931-560f-4b4c-888b-255d97713ff9.label: Radian Definition
f0341931-560f-4b4c-888b-255d97713ff9.description: One radian is the measure of a central angle that intercepts an arc length equal to the radius of the circle.
examples: Illustrating a radian on a unit circle
Defining the relationship between arc length and radius

074f77af-7c4a-42b0-95b4-b8ab64eb9b63.label: Conversion Formulas
074f77af-7c4a-42b0-95b4-b8ab64eb9b63.description: Degrees to radians: radians = degrees * (π/180). Radians to degrees: degrees = radians * (180/π).
examples: Applying the conversion formula to 30 degrees
Using the radian to degree conversion formula

37979b0d-5ea6-445a-878c-baa1b7fa9935.label: Degree-Radian Conversion
37979b0d-5ea6-445a-878c-baa1b7fa9935.description: To convert degrees to radians, multiply by π/180. To convert radians to degrees, multiply by 180/π.

7a49de8f-da8a-488e-a2cf-0b49dfe98b5c.label: Degree and Radian Measure
7a49de8f-da8a-488e-a2cf-0b49dfe98b5c.description: Understanding degree measure as a fraction of a circular rotation and converting between degrees and radians.

d1ccdc13-209f-408c-9de6-87ef5c21834c.label: Adding/Subtracting Multiples
d1ccdc13-209f-408c-9de6-87ef5c21834c.description: Adding or subtracting 360° (or 2π) to find coterminal angles.
examples: Coterminal angle of 60 degrees is 60 + 360 = 420 degrees
Coterminal angle of pi/4 radians is pi/4 - 2pi = -7pi/4 radians

d05b9959-6779-444e-ac92-379909be7621.label: Coterminal Angle Definition
d05b9959-6779-444e-ac92-379909be7621.description: Coterminal angles share the same initial and terminal sides. Found by adding or subtracting multiples of 360° (2π radians).
examples: Finding a positive coterminal angle for -90 degrees
Finding a negative coterminal angle for 45 degrees

a3817f09-00b4-479c-9e0d-ee22c628c905.label: Importance of Radians
a3817f09-00b4-479c-9e0d-ee22c628c905.description: The arc length formula s=rθ is only valid when θ is measured in radians.
examples: If the angle is in degrees, convert to radians before using formula
Using the correct unit for consistent calculations

0aded222-2218-4992-ad8a-1c318dbdf3a2.label: Arc Length Formula
0aded222-2218-4992-ad8a-1c318dbdf3a2.description: Arc length (s) is the distance along a circular arc, calculated using the formula s = rθ, where r is the radius and θ is the central angle in radians.
examples: Calculating arc length with a radius of 5 and an angle of pi/3
Finding the distance traveled along a circular path

80f48ba2-6517-4d8c-b754-53e08365cf33.label: Coterminal Angles and Arc Length
80f48ba2-6517-4d8c-b754-53e08365cf33.description: Finding angles that share the same terminal side and calculating the length of a circular arc.
examples: Calculating the arc length of a sector with a central angle of pi/4

3f2ee9d1-35a8-4dff-9c37-b2d7feedbd16.label: Units for Angular Speed
3f2ee9d1-35a8-4dff-9c37-b2d7feedbd16.description: Common units include radians per second (rad/s) or radians per minute (rad/min).

47307248-1ca2-4e04-98cc-2f38b1d580ab.label: Angular Speed Definition
47307248-1ca2-4e04-98cc-2f38b1d580ab.description: Angular speed (ω) is the rate of change of the central angle with respect to time: ω = θ/t, where θ is in radians and t is time.
examples: Calculating angular speed in radians per second
Determining the rate of rotation of a spinning object

9727991b-076f-4661-80e5-73d06f357b5d.label: Units for Linear Speed
9727991b-076f-4661-80e5-73d06f357b5d.description: Common units include meters per second (m/s), feet per second (ft/s), or miles per hour (mph).

ac12503d-a834-4313-9b9c-08dcb3793331.label: Linear Speed Definition
ac12503d-a834-4313-9b9c-08dcb3793331.description: Linear speed (v) is the distance traveled along a circular path per unit time: v = s/t, where s is arc length and t is time.
examples: Calculating linear speed in meters per second
Determining the speed of a car moving around a circular track

c16273e0-5504-4a80-85e3-5f79642c4f61.label: Formula Application
c16273e0-5504-4a80-85e3-5f79642c4f61.description: The formula v=rω connects angular and linear motion.
examples: Calculating speed of a point on a tire

2d058639-3f5f-41d6-95c0-d289bb8ffa07.label: Relating Linear and Angular Speed
2d058639-3f5f-41d6-95c0-d289bb8ffa07.description: The relationship is v = rω, where v is linear speed, r is the radius, and ω is angular speed in radians per unit time.
examples: Calculating linear speed from angular speed and radius
Determining angular speed from linear speed and radius

068f9d4a-075d-4a68-a7c9-8ee3d40090ee.label: Linear and Angular Speed
068f9d4a-075d-4a68-a7c9-8ee3d40090ee.description: Relating linear speed (distance traveled along a circular path per unit time) and angular speed (rate of change of the central angle).
examples: Calculating the linear speed of a point on a rotating wheel
Finding the angular speed of a spinning object

555a2cdf-2931-49b1-a547-f0fb70e2b735.label: Angles and Trigonometric Functions
555a2cdf-2931-49b1-a547-f0fb70e2b735.description: Exploration of angles, their measurement, and their applications in trigonometric functions. Covers standard position, degree/radian conversion, coterminal angles, arc length, and linear/angular speed.
examples: Golf swing involving specific angles for optimal ball trajectory
Navigation using angles for course correction

433e3515-884e-4fba-918f-50e488c90356.label: sin²(θ) + cos²(θ) = 1
433e3515-884e-4fba-918f-50e488c90356.description: The core Pythagorean identity; all other Pythagorean identities can be derived from this.
examples: Verifying identities by substituting equivalent expressions

7b7b397a-903e-4acf-bcc4-b2dbcfad8c15.label: 1 + tan²(θ) = sec²(θ)
7b7b397a-903e-4acf-bcc4-b2dbcfad8c15.description: Useful in simplifying expressions involving tangent and secant functions
examples: Replacing sec²(θ) with 1+tan²(θ) to simplify an equation.
Simplifying expressions involving both tan and sec.

27262204-32f2-43d9-847c-ad159d4b472c.label: 1 + cot²(θ) = csc²(θ)
27262204-32f2-43d9-847c-ad159d4b472c.description: Useful in simplifying expressions involving cotangent and cosecant functions
examples: Replacing csc²(θ) with 1+cot²(θ) in an equation.
Simplifying expressions with both cot and csc.

5db143a1-9edc-4bf8-a1d1-dcdf800c4cb4.label: Pythagorean Identities
5db143a1-9edc-4bf8-a1d1-dcdf800c4cb4.description: Relate squares of trigonometric functions, derived from the unit circle and the Pythagorean theorem. Essential for simplifying expressions.

6a13e862-16a5-4f5d-bbba-25957a39e635.label: Cosine and Secant Even
6a13e862-16a5-4f5d-bbba-25957a39e635.description: cos(-θ) = cos(θ) and sec(-θ) = sec(θ) imply symmetry across the y-axis.

a1568f19-ae96-490a-8461-bfcbb8af9f00.label: Sine, Tangent, Cosecant, Cotangent Odd
a1568f19-ae96-490a-8461-bfcbb8af9f00.description: sin(-θ) = -sin(θ), tan(-θ) = -tan(θ), csc(-θ) = -csc(θ), and cot(-θ) = -cot(θ) imply symmetry about the origin.

81cce03c-17bc-40f1-9d86-bf3b759025f4.label: Even-Odd Identities
81cce03c-17bc-40f1-9d86-bf3b759025f4.description: Define how trigonometric functions behave with negative angles, indicating symmetry about the origin or y-axis.

d384048c-4420-4f90-bb16-ec3d2688843c.label: csc(θ) = 1/sin(θ)
d384048c-4420-4f90-bb16-ec3d2688843c.description: Cosecant is the reciprocal of sine

fcf1eaed-0134-44ff-869e-328464ab824f.label: sec(θ) = 1/cos(θ)
fcf1eaed-0134-44ff-869e-328464ab824f.description: Secant is the reciprocal of cosine

3faf88e6-c5dd-4f89-8d05-983ae3c1dbb4.label: cot(θ) = 1/tan(θ)
3faf88e6-c5dd-4f89-8d05-983ae3c1dbb4.description: Cotangent is the reciprocal of tangent

b492097b-c674-4198-9746-6a81a6b26957.label: Reciprocal Identities
b492097b-c674-4198-9746-6a81a6b26957.description: Define trigonometric functions as reciprocals of each other; critical for simplification.

842fa1be-63d1-4950-bb53-b40b5d8c3bcb.label: tan(θ) = sin(θ)/cos(θ)
842fa1be-63d1-4950-bb53-b40b5d8c3bcb.description: Tangent is sine divided by cosine
examples: Expressing tangent in terms of sine and cosine

b523acf8-1038-457d-91ee-5c406e16459d.label: cot(θ) = cos(θ)/sin(θ)
b523acf8-1038-457d-91ee-5c406e16459d.description: Cotangent is cosine divided by sine
examples: Expressing cotangent in terms of sine and cosine

461d46db-305f-4c6f-99ae-659c6c548997.label: Quotient Identities
461d46db-305f-4c6f-99ae-659c6c548997.description: Express tangent and cotangent in terms of sine and cosine.

86a24e22-cbe1-4939-9509-87ed2f9d96c3.label: Fundamental Trigonometric Identities
86a24e22-cbe1-4939-9509-87ed2f9d96c3.description: These identities form the basis for simplifying and solving trigonometric equations. Includes Pythagorean, even-odd, reciprocal, and quotient identities.

c5c72819-4619-4618-9d29-82aaa83a7795.label: Factoring Trigonometric Expressions
c5c72819-4619-4618-9d29-82aaa83a7795.description: Applying factoring techniques to trigonometric expressions to simplify them.
examples: Factoring sin²(x) - cos²(x) into (sin(x) + cos(x))(sin(x) - cos(x))

bed10d84-c480-40c4-ac04-720597d86fd0.label: Expanding Trigonometric Expressions
bed10d84-c480-40c4-ac04-720597d86fd0.description: Using algebraic expansion to simplify trigonometric expressions.

6737922a-781b-446e-81ca-9ccb4ee31352.label: Finding Common Denominators
6737922a-781b-446e-81ca-9ccb4ee31352.description: Combining trigonometric fractions by finding a common denominator.
examples: Adding fractions with trigonometric functions in the denominator

25df3b50-0ce7-422a-a976-1af16721619c.label: Simplification Strategies
25df3b50-0ce7-422a-a976-1af16721619c.description: Techniques to simplify one side: factoring, expanding, finding common denominators, converting to sines and cosines.

78a4cd3a-0301-4d9d-87b2-712dd49e6fab.label: Converting to Sines and Cosines
78a4cd3a-0301-4d9d-87b2-712dd49e6fab.description: Expressing all trigonometric functions in terms of sine and cosine to simplify.
examples: Expressing all functions in terms of sin and cos.

0058287a-950a-4c6d-978a-40789facb1e7.label: Using Even-Odd Identities
0058287a-950a-4c6d-978a-40789facb1e7.description: Applying even-odd identities to simplify expressions involving negative angles.
examples: Using even-odd to simplify complex equations

3854f5fc-dede-4969-94ab-6d5b09babc77.label: Verifying Trigonometric Identities
3854f5fc-dede-4969-94ab-6d5b09babc77.description: Process of proving that a trigonometric equation is true for all values. Start with the more complicated side and simplify using identities.
examples: Using even-odd identities to simplify expressions

f43b27e1-5d4e-407d-bf75-b1f06c775cad.label: Recognizing Algebraic Patterns
f43b27e1-5d4e-407d-bf75-b1f06c775cad.description: Identifying patterns like difference of squares or perfect squares in trigonometric expressions.
examples: Recognizing sin^2(x) - cos^2(x) as a difference of squares

5f34729c-8b20-4663-9234-618df348dd8c.label: Using Substitution
5f34729c-8b20-4663-9234-618df348dd8c.description: Substituting a variable (e.g., u = sin(x)) to simplify complex trigonometric expressions.
examples: Letting u = sin(x) to simplify sin^2(x) + 2sin(x) + 1
Using substitution to solve complex equations

b7a7e743-c917-4318-8494-7b69e14e0931.label: Applying Special Algebraic Formulas
b7a7e743-c917-4318-8494-7b69e14e0931.description: Using formulas like (a+b)^2 = a^2 + 2ab + b^2 or (a^2 - b^2) = (a+b)(a-b) to simplify.
examples: Expanding (sin(x) + cos(x))^2 using the perfect square formula
Factoring sin⁴(x) - cos⁴(x) using the difference of squares

041b7922-1400-4a25-90eb-0dde17819502.label: Algebraic Simplification of Trigonometric Expressions
041b7922-1400-4a25-90eb-0dde17819502.description: Applying algebraic properties and formulas (difference of squares, perfect squares, substitution) to simplify trigonometric expressions.
examples: Rewriting sin^4(x) - cos^4(x) using the difference of squares

13fb3893-b7b6-4263-a1fc-1ef384552fe0.label: Solving Trigonometric Equations Using Identities
13fb3893-b7b6-4263-a1fc-1ef384552fe0.description: Using trigonometric identities to simplify trigonometric expressions and solve equations, mirroring algebraic techniques like factoring and substitution. Identities act as alternate representations to facilitate solutions.

bb7599ab-c099-4f9d-ad83-845484749e7e.label: Real and Imaginary Axes
bb7599ab-c099-4f9d-ad83-845484749e7e.description: The horizontal axis represents real numbers, while the vertical axis represents imaginary numbers.

36584aef-2b92-4195-8b5f-0891e7158b74.label: Point Representation
36584aef-2b92-4195-8b5f-0891e7158b74.description: A complex number a + bi is represented by the point (a, b) on the complex plane.

f2d4fc4d-510c-42ac-a5ce-7f7f288f48be.label: Plotting Complex Numbers
f2d4fc4d-510c-42ac-a5ce-7f7f288f48be.description: Mapping complex numbers (a + bi) as points (a, b) on the complex plane, with the real part on the horizontal axis.

a1feb48b-b694-473d-97af-0a73658c7734.label: Formula
a1feb48b-b694-473d-97af-0a73658c7734.description: The formula for calculating the absolute value is |a + bi| = sqrt(a^2 + b^2).

2b47cb27-d8e1-466d-abe4-d33c8db56144.label: Geometric Interpretation
2b47cb27-d8e1-466d-abe4-d33c8db56144.description: Represents the length of the vector from the origin to the point representing the complex number.
examples: A vector from (0,0) to (3,4) has length 5

d82ab985-e1e4-40b2-aeca-c180f7fae57f.label: Absolute Value (Modulus)
d82ab985-e1e4-40b2-aeca-c180f7fae57f.description: The distance from the origin to the point representing the complex number on the complex plane, calculated as |a + bi| = sqrt(a^2 + b^2).

4d413f06-88e7-4124-bbcf-576abe1fc131.label: Complex Plane & Absolute Value
4d413f06-88e7-4124-bbcf-576abe1fc131.description: Understanding the representation of complex numbers on the complex plane and calculating their absolute values (moduli).

a6c785f1-e42c-4596-a65c-9899325339ff.label: Finding Modulus (r)
a6c785f1-e42c-4596-a65c-9899325339ff.description: Calculate the modulus using r = sqrt(a^2 + b^2), representing the distance from the origin.

442f20e5-01d0-4fc2-a76a-e55f9e191d32.label: Finding Argument (θ)
442f20e5-01d0-4fc2-a76a-e55f9e191d32.description: Determine the argument using tan θ = b/a, adjusting for the correct quadrant of the complex number.

256dbb9c-3343-48ea-b6f1-ed41a54a2f53.label: Rectangular to Polar
256dbb9c-3343-48ea-b6f1-ed41a54a2f53.description: Finding the modulus (r) using r = sqrt(a^2 + b^2) and the argument (θ) using tan θ = b/a, considering the quadrant.

0c9305f2-3b84-439d-8d09-44003133116c.label: Real Part Calculation
0c9305f2-3b84-439d-8d09-44003133116c.description: Calculate the real part 'a' using the formula a = r cos θ.

597f426d-dcd6-401c-b0bc-e653f7abf3a6.label: Imaginary Part Calculation
597f426d-dcd6-401c-b0bc-e653f7abf3a6.description: Calculate the imaginary part 'b' using the formula b = r sin θ.

dad4b8f6-eea7-447c-aed2-bf83fc60a1e5.label: Polar to Rectangular
dad4b8f6-eea7-447c-aed2-bf83fc60a1e5.description: Using the relationships a = r cos θ and b = r sin θ to find the real and imaginary parts of the complex number.

31a80fb0-1efe-4cc3-84da-565a18ff1eca.label: Polar and Rectangular Conversion
31a80fb0-1efe-4cc3-84da-565a18ff1eca.description: Converting complex numbers between rectangular (a + bi) and polar (r(cos θ + i sin θ)) forms using trigonometric relationships.
examples: Converting 2(cos(π/3) + i sin(π/3)) to rectangular form

61ffcc95-9604-4e16-b074-691d50e4db94.label: Multiplication Rule
61ffcc95-9604-4e16-b074-691d50e4db94.description: To multiply complex numbers, multiply their moduli and add their arguments.
examples: If z1 = 2(cos(π/4) + i sin(π/4)) and z2 = 3(cos(π/6) + i sin(π/6)), z1*z2 = 6(cos(5π/12) + i sin(5π/12))

50ab10d3-02f7-446d-a655-37af912c280d.label: Division Rule
50ab10d3-02f7-446d-a655-37af912c280d.description: To divide complex numbers, divide their moduli and subtract their arguments.
examples: If z1 = 2(cos(π/4) + i sin(π/4)) and z2 = 3(cos(π/6) + i sin(π/6)), z1/z2 = (2/3)(cos(π/12) + i sin(π/12))

04a9f1f7-0f5c-4733-80a3-b083b2dc5411.label: Multiplication and Division
04a9f1f7-0f5c-4733-80a3-b083b2dc5411.description: Multiplying moduli and adding arguments for multiplication; dividing moduli and subtracting arguments for division.
examples: z1 = r1(cos θ1 + i sin θ1), z2 = r2(cos θ2 + i sin θ2)
z1 * z2 = r1r2(cos(θ1 + θ2) + i sin(θ1 + θ2))

144591d9-43d6-43e7-9c91-6de6ea80ff3f.label: Applying the Theorem
144591d9-43d6-43e7-9c91-6de6ea80ff3f.description: Raise the modulus to the power 'n' and multiply the argument by 'n'.

e9a3517e-5125-4d3e-9a60-226b360a0b2a.label: Resulting Expression
e9a3517e-5125-4d3e-9a60-226b360a0b2a.description: The result is r^n(cos(nθ) + i sin(nθ)).

04488222-fb1a-4df3-887b-8aa2feea55fd.label: De Moivre's Theorem
04488222-fb1a-4df3-887b-8aa2feea55fd.description: Raising a complex number to a power n by raising the modulus to the power n and multiplying the argument by n: [r(cos θ + i sin θ)]^n = r^n(cos(nθ) + i sin(nθ)).
examples: (cos θ + i sin θ)^2 = cos(2θ) + i sin(2θ)

01f8c658-bb95-4ea3-80ff-72f654a4b05e.label: Root Theorem Formula
01f8c658-bb95-4ea3-80ff-72f654a4b05e.description: The formula for finding the nth roots is z_k = r^(1/n) * [cos((θ + 2πk)/n) + i sin((θ + 2πk)/n)]
examples: Cube roots of 8: z_k = 2[cos((0 + 2πk)/3) + i sin((0 + 2πk)/3)]

b1e0792c-b479-4ac5-8921-a897e936824f.label: Periodic Roots
b1e0792c-b479-4ac5-8921-a897e936824f.description: The addition of 2πk accounts for the periodic nature of trigonometric functions, generating 'n' distinct roots.

0c671fcf-debf-45b6-9bab-4cd010400d5e.label: Finding Roots
0c671fcf-debf-45b6-9bab-4cd010400d5e.description: Calculating the nth roots of a complex number using the formula: z_k = r^(1/n) * [cos((θ + 2πk)/n) + i sin((θ + 2πk)/n)], where k = 0, 1, ..., n-1.
examples: Finding the square roots of i

fa687517-0e87-43c4-be28-bf8e2b117a56.label: Operations and De Moivre's Theorem
fa687517-0e87-43c4-be28-bf8e2b117a56.description: Performing multiplication, division, exponentiation, and root extraction on complex numbers using their polar representations and De Moivre's Theorem.
examples: Finding (1 + i)^5 using De Moivre's Theorem

9e1e620d-4b57-4669-ae09-7fe572cc2264.label: Polar Form of Complex Numbers
9e1e620d-4b57-4669-ae09-7fe572cc2264.description: Exploration of complex numbers using polar coordinates, including plotting, conversion between forms, operations, and De Moivre's Theorem.
examples: Finding the product of two complex numbers in polar form

f28ae8b0-7a1d-4ddd-896c-a16992b69fc3.label: Properties of Identity Matrix
f28ae8b0-7a1d-4ddd-896c-a16992b69fc3.description: It is a square matrix with 1s on the diagonal. Multiplying any matrix by the identity matrix results in the original matrix.

4fd45c44-a8cd-4bab-a973-48769225df83.label: Multiplicative Inverse Requirement
4fd45c44-a8cd-4bab-a973-48769225df83.description: Only square matrices can possess multiplicative inverses; non-square matrices cannot be inverted.
examples: A 2x2 matrix may have an inverse
A 2x3 matrix cannot have an inverse

f6369427-cf4b-4257-b3c2-16165de5b30b.label: Identity Matrix Definition
f6369427-cf4b-4257-b3c2-16165de5b30b.description: The identity matrix (I) is a square matrix with 1s on the main diagonal and 0s elsewhere; acts as '1' in matrix multiplication.

f4404c22-51cd-4d8d-a26e-15a0b5fd5f0d.label: Uniqueness of Inverse
f4404c22-51cd-4d8d-a26e-15a0b5fd5f0d.description: If a square matrix A has an inverse, then that inverse (A⁻¹) is unique; there is only one such inverse.
examples: If A*B=I and A*C=I then B=C
A matrix cannot have two different inverses

9c8c62de-a17e-44bd-8442-8e6ebc3a9853.label: Verification of Inverse
9c8c62de-a17e-44bd-8442-8e6ebc3a9853.description: To verify if matrix B is the inverse of A, check if A*B = B*A = I, where I is the identity matrix.
examples: If A*B = I and B*A = I, B is A's inverse.

9598a84a-0e3a-42b2-8b4a-45b16bdb4bd7.label: Invertible Matrix Definition
9598a84a-0e3a-42b2-8b4a-45b16bdb4bd7.description: A matrix is invertible if there exists another matrix such that their product equals the identity matrix; not all square matrices are invertible.

5cdfd26e-5638-471b-bcb2-7911a74e9d1c.label: Understanding Matrix Inverses
5cdfd26e-5638-471b-bcb2-7911a74e9d1c.description: Defining multiplicative inverses for matrices, analogous to real numbers, resulting in the identity matrix. Exploring invertible matrices and their properties.
examples: If A is invertible, A⁻¹ is unique

1db8cb65-9770-44e4-94a1-03f3a7a99205.label: Limitations of this method
1db8cb65-9770-44e4-94a1-03f3a7a99205.description: This method becomes computationally intensive and less practical for larger matrices due to the increasing complexity of equations.
examples: Prone to errors with manual calculations

91ec0c23-5497-47be-ae7c-02dd397c16a8.label: Using Matrix Multiplication for Inverse
91ec0c23-5497-47be-ae7c-02dd397c16a8.description: Setting up an equation where A * X = I, with X containing unknown constants, and solving for the constants to find A⁻¹.
examples: Solving for a, b, c, d

45f31e75-49eb-48a2-86f1-c263cdd7357b.label: Row Operations
45f31e75-49eb-48a2-86f1-c263cdd7357b.description: Using row operations: interchanging rows, multiplying a row by a constant, and adding multiples of rows to others, to transform matrix A to I.

4452d6be-9b16-4a0d-be85-93f7d571cc0f.label: Efficiency of Augmentation
4452d6be-9b16-4a0d-be85-93f7d571cc0f.description: Generally more efficient than matrix multiplication for larger matrices and is a core technique in linear algebra.

c335ee15-3282-4015-af24-6568ba02f369.label: Augmenting with the Identity
c335ee15-3282-4015-af24-6568ba02f369.description: Creating an augmented matrix [A | I] and performing row operations until A is transformed into I, at which point the augmented side is A⁻¹.
examples: Performing row operations to get identity

32dd673e-48b2-405d-82b2-686e6ab78b86.label: Determinant Calculation
32dd673e-48b2-405d-82b2-686e6ab78b86.description: The determinant (det(A)) is calculated as ad - bc for a 2x2 matrix A = [[a, b], [c, d]]; if det(A) = 0, the matrix has no inverse.

7623ea2c-03fe-4127-9d05-d264877dbdb0.label: Applying the Formula
7623ea2c-03fe-4127-9d05-d264877dbdb0.description: After calculating the determinant, apply the formula by swapping a and d, negating b and c, and multiplying by 1/det(A).

610769d2-6bef-43a8-a945-094c26d798e3.label: Formula for 2x2 Inverses
610769d2-6bef-43a8-a945-094c26d798e3.description: Using the formula: A⁻¹ = (1/det(A)) * [[d, -b], [-c, a]], where det(A) = ad - bc, for a 2x2 matrix A = [[a, b], [c, d]].

5d80a1f8-7a28-4072-a043-31d3e0ce5b0a.label: Methods for Finding Inverses
5d80a1f8-7a28-4072-a043-31d3e0ce5b0a.description: Exploring various techniques to determine the multiplicative inverse of a matrix, including matrix multiplication, augmenting with the identity, and a formula for 2x2 matrices.
examples: Setting up equations to find A⁻¹

f45562df-2e8f-4a17-866f-587a0fcb2686.label: Matrix Equation Form
f45562df-2e8f-4a17-866f-587a0fcb2686.description: Representing a system of equations in the form AX = B, where A is the coefficient matrix, X is the variable matrix, and B is the constant matrix.

fcb2b31f-1782-426f-96b6-af8731970d56.label: Solving for the Variable Matrix
fcb2b31f-1782-426f-96b6-af8731970d56.description: Multiplying both sides of AX = B by A⁻¹ on the left yields A⁻¹AX = A⁻¹B, which simplifies to X = A⁻¹B, giving the solution.

ff52de57-c389-4137-a81a-64354984c466.label: Applicability and Limitations
ff52de57-c389-4137-a81a-64354984c466.description: This method works only for systems with a unique solution (i.e., where the coefficient matrix is invertible). If A is not invertible, other methods are needed.

adf834bd-4ee9-4083-8538-0f62c08fd5bf.label: Solving Systems with Inverse Matrices
adf834bd-4ee9-4083-8538-0f62c08fd5bf.description: Applying inverse matrices to solve systems of linear equations. The solution is found by X = A⁻¹B, where A is the coefficient matrix and B is the constant matrix.

b445ed24-65e2-4a01-8462-9c1f58b3bac6.label: Solving Systems Using Matrix Inverses
b445ed24-65e2-4a01-8462-9c1f58b3bac6.description: Exploration of matrix inverses, their properties, and their application in solving systems of linear equations, including 2x2 and larger systems. Emphasis on computational methods.
examples: Finding unique solutions to linear equations

a1e16281-e469-4ebe-8049-987f5bbc2996.label: Calculating Common Difference
a1e16281-e469-4ebe-8049-987f5bbc2996.description: Subtracting any term from its subsequent term within the sequence. This difference must remain constant for the sequence to be arithmetic.

5f8546d5-a25e-480b-913a-082a4aad9e12.label: Non-Arithmetic Sequences
5f8546d5-a25e-480b-913a-082a4aad9e12.description: Sequences that do not exhibit a constant difference between terms. Recognizing these is vital before attempting to apply arithmetic sequence formulas.

b5d27ae3-da9c-40d0-8487-7ac781eb7fc5.label: Definition of Common Difference
b5d27ae3-da9c-40d0-8487-7ac781eb7fc5.description: The constant value added or subtracted between consecutive terms in an arithmetic sequence. Essential for identifying and defining arithmetic sequences.
examples: Found by subtracting a term from its successor

aa350802-8931-4254-9453-20637bb6cb25.label: Constant Rate of Change
aa350802-8931-4254-9453-20637bb6cb25.description: Arithmetic sequences have a constant rate of change which is the common difference between the terms.
examples: Each term changes by the same amount
Not true for geometric or other sequences

89884641-ce1f-424d-9ec4-f9c60226e797.label: Graphical Representation
89884641-ce1f-424d-9ec4-f9c60226e797.description: The graph of an arithmetic sequence consists of discrete points that lie on a straight line. This visually confirms the constant rate of change.
examples: Plotting terms shows a linear pattern
Allows for visual confirmation of common difference

29c7d9d3-9805-4988-b503-7724945bb96c.label: Linearity and Arithmetic Sequences
29c7d9d3-9805-4988-b503-7724945bb96c.description: Arithmetic sequences represent linear functions, meaning their graphs form a straight line. Common difference corresponds to the slope.
examples: Graph of 2, 4, 6, 8 is a straight line

439f3969-c351-4053-bff3-7651a48af8fd.label: Identifying Common Differences in Sequences
439f3969-c351-4053-bff3-7651a48af8fd.description: Determining if a sequence is arithmetic by checking for a constant difference between consecutive terms.  Crucial for applying arithmetic sequence formulas.

cacea032-05b6-4be6-b904-d8afd275aec7.label: Iterative Process
cacea032-05b6-4be6-b904-d8afd275aec7.description: The process of repeatedly applying the common difference to generate subsequent terms.
examples: Adding the common difference to the previous term

a5fc16b8-3575-425c-9170-17c4c9789ffb.label: Using First Term & Common Difference
a5fc16b8-3575-425c-9170-17c4c9789ffb.description: Starting with the initial term and repeatedly adding the common difference to obtain subsequent terms. A fundamental method.
examples: Easy to generate first few terms

eb1094df-9bd4-4bb4-ae52-a318902026f3.label: Explicit Formula Application
eb1094df-9bd4-4bb4-ae52-a318902026f3.description: Using the formula an = a1 + (n-1)d to directly calculate the nth term of the sequence.

76391386-6dcc-4181-b4cd-3eb77be6fd84.label: Finding a Specific Term
76391386-6dcc-4181-b4cd-3eb77be6fd84.description: Calculating a specific term (e.g., the 10th term) directly, without calculating all preceding terms. Uses the explicit formula.
examples: Finding a10 without listing a1 to a9

3db6df36-cac6-4cbf-abd5-57d11be273e7.label: Writing Terms of Arithmetic Sequences
3db6df36-cac6-4cbf-abd5-57d11be273e7.description: Generating the terms of a sequence given the first term and common difference. Essential for understanding how arithmetic sequences progress.
examples: Illustrates how each term is built from the previous

c43f33cc-c180-4902-acf4-cd0f5af9bc63.label: Initial Term Requirement
c43f33cc-c180-4902-acf4-cd0f5af9bc63.description: Recursive formulas always require the specification of the initial term(s) to begin the sequence.
examples: Without a1, the sequence cannot be generated
Provides the base case for the recursion

54a5f0c1-30dd-4530-830a-0ef5690da0c5.label: Understanding Recursive Formula
54a5f0c1-30dd-4530-830a-0ef5690da0c5.description: Each term is defined as the sum of the previous term and the common difference. The first term is always given.
examples: Defines how to get the next term

4f8f3119-d526-4506-8f13-f36e984306a2.label: Iterative Calculation
4f8f3119-d526-4506-8f13-f36e984306a2.description: The process of repeatedly substituting previous terms into the recursive formula to generate the sequence.
examples: Calculating each term based on the one before
Building the sequence step by step

ffe206c2-6340-4554-aa66-6d350d4a16a7.label: Applying Recursive Formula
ffe206c2-6340-4554-aa66-6d350d4a16a7.description: Substituting the value of the previous term into the formula to calculate the next term in the sequence.

2739c182-9cc7-432a-83ae-6f20aebb716b.label: Recursive Formulas for Arithmetic Sequences
2739c182-9cc7-432a-83ae-6f20aebb716b.description: Defining a sequence where each term depends on the previous term.  Useful for expressing relationships between terms.

f7be133c-1b26-40b0-844e-be51761138f2.label: Relationship to Linear Functions
f7be133c-1b26-40b0-844e-be51761138f2.description: Arithmetic sequences are linear functions with a common difference corresponding to the slope.
examples: The common difference is the slope

78d302cc-5c4d-4f2d-8a69-c78b2927b971.label: Understanding Explicit Formula
78d302cc-5c4d-4f2d-8a69-c78b2927b971.description: The nth term is defined as the sum of the first term and (n-1) times the common difference. Key for direct term retrieval.

cad3e487-73f3-44f5-806f-a36c88c1144c.label: Direct Term Calculation
cad3e487-73f3-44f5-806f-a36c88c1144c.description: Calculating the value of a specific term by substituting its position into the explicit formula.
examples: Finding the value of the 10th term
No need to know previous terms

3d550c59-d408-40b8-8bf0-35d0767f0814.label: Applying Explicit Formula
3d550c59-d408-40b8-8bf0-35d0767f0814.description: Substituting the values of the first term, common difference, and term position into the formula.  Directly determines the term's value.

02837e4c-926e-4855-8c5b-1772d14217c2.label: Explicit Formulas for Arithmetic Sequences
02837e4c-926e-4855-8c5b-1772d14217c2.description: Defining a sequence where any term can be directly calculated based on its position.  Provides a direct calculation method.

dfb6f7d6-0854-43e4-ba69-b92b11949edb.label: Solving for Term Position
dfb6f7d6-0854-43e4-ba69-b92b11949edb.description: Isolating the variable 'n' in the explicit formula to determine the position of the last term, which represents the total number of terms.
examples: Finding the total number of terms

edcb4cd8-1799-4e73-b3f1-c7a70831a104.label: Using Explicit Formula and Last Term
edcb4cd8-1799-4e73-b3f1-c7a70831a104.description: Substituting the last term of the sequence into the explicit formula and solving for n. Requires knowing the last term.

a1e91564-27d3-4a90-af36-4a39f3492437.label: Finding Number of Terms in Finite Sequence
a1e91564-27d3-4a90-af36-4a39f3492437.description: Determining the total number of terms in a finite arithmetic sequence using the explicit formula.  Useful for bounded sequences.
examples: Given a1, d, and an, find n

796605a3-50ff-4ce1-a7c9-14fd0f041628.label: Identifying Initial Term and Difference
796605a3-50ff-4ce1-a7c9-14fd0f041628.description: Determining the starting value and the constant change per period from the problem statement.
examples: The initial value is the first term
The constant change is the common difference

6cb35dfa-3807-468f-a981-75c429155ddb.label: Modeling Real-World Scenarios
6cb35dfa-3807-468f-a981-75c429155ddb.description: Using arithmetic sequences to represent quantities that increase or decrease at a constant rate. Essential for problem-solving.
examples: Depreciation as a decreasing arithmetic sequence

03837340-e773-4176-8ae5-4d1cda1225c8.label: Relating Math to Reality
03837340-e773-4176-8ae5-4d1cda1225c8.description: Connecting the mathematical solution to the real-world situation to provide a meaningful answer.
examples: The calculated truck value is the estimated selling price
The calculated allowance is the predicted weekly amount

01fd9adf-e0c1-422e-bea2-776c7e91e08d.label: Interpreting Results
01fd9adf-e0c1-422e-bea2-776c7e91e08d.description: Understanding the meaning of calculated values in the context of the application problem. Connecting math to reality.

76cff151-7ce0-4ece-ae3e-b0d3c44f081a.label: Solving Application Problems
76cff151-7ce0-4ece-ae3e-b0d3c44f081a.description: Applying arithmetic sequence concepts to real-world scenarios, such as depreciation and allowance calculations. Demonstrates practical use.

b374892a-2222-431f-8a21-71818fce8db6.label: Arithmetic Sequences: Definition, Formulas, Applications
b374892a-2222-431f-8a21-71818fce8db6.description: Exploration of arithmetic sequences, including identifying common differences, writing terms, using recursive and explicit formulas, and solving application problems.

271b28ab-51e9-4da0-b245-3c420a3af722.label: Finding Common Difference
271b28ab-51e9-4da0-b245-3c420a3af722.description: The common difference 'd' is found by subtracting any term from its subsequent term in the sequence.

d240e0e5-c08d-4d50-808f-3e084035f3a7.label: Identifying Arithmetic Sequences
d240e0e5-c08d-4d50-808f-3e084035f3a7.description: To determine if a sequence is arithmetic, check if the difference between consecutive terms is constant throughout the sequence.

94cd3681-0695-4ec7-b352-cbe0a3659f03.label: Defining Arithmetic Sequences
94cd3681-0695-4ec7-b352-cbe0a3659f03.description: An arithmetic sequence is a list of numbers with a constant difference between consecutive terms, called the common difference.

911bc7b4-8014-43d2-bd67-f8ff77141ad0.label: Defining Initial Term
911bc7b4-8014-43d2-bd67-f8ff77141ad0.description: Recursive formulas require an initial term (a_1) to start the sequence. This is the first number in the sequence.

2968bcb8-635a-4ea2-aeb3-f3a44445092c.label: Applying Recursive Formula
2968bcb8-635a-4ea2-aeb3-f3a44445092c.description: To find subsequent terms, add the common difference to the previous term defined by recursive formula.

7195a025-8e79-4a50-b7ba-b90defdbc70e.label: Recursive Formula for Arithmetic
7195a025-8e79-4a50-b7ba-b90defdbc70e.description: A recursive formula defines each term based on the previous term and the common difference: a_n = a_(n-1) + d.

ae33f8fe-81d5-4059-9db1-888744e1b858.label: Using Explicit Formula
ae33f8fe-81d5-4059-9db1-888744e1b858.description: To find a specific term, substitute the term number 'n' into the explicit formula.

c655c11f-f139-4b43-9f6f-97588fa3ad44.label: Finding Number of Terms
c655c11f-f139-4b43-9f6f-97588fa3ad44.description: The explicit formula can be rearranged to find the number of terms if the last term is known.
examples: Using explicit formula to solve for n

9340627e-4735-49f7-b5d8-812ec4c8606e.label: Explicit Formula for Arithmetic
9340627e-4735-49f7-b5d8-812ec4c8606e.description: An explicit formula defines each term based on its position (n) in the sequence: a_n = a_1 + (n-1)d.

b94cc219-7101-43b5-b03a-656f11d4b9e7.label: Understanding Arithmetic Sequences
b94cc219-7101-43b5-b03a-656f11d4b9e7.description: Defines arithmetic sequences, common difference, recursive and explicit formulas. Focuses on identifying and generating arithmetic sequences.

b689bc47-ad6d-4c13-844c-96e33be248ff.label: Finding Common Ratio
b689bc47-ad6d-4c13-844c-96e33be248ff.description: The common ratio 'r' is found by dividing any term by its previous term in the sequence.

07c2ea01-4504-4372-a8db-f74394f8ca57.label: Identifying Geometric Sequences
07c2ea01-4504-4372-a8db-f74394f8ca57.description: To determine if a sequence is geometric, check if the ratio between consecutive terms is constant.

1584131a-ab34-46ae-bd32-b8704d06a069.label: Defining Geometric Sequences
1584131a-ab34-46ae-bd32-b8704d06a069.description: A geometric sequence is a list of numbers where the ratio between consecutive terms is constant, called the common ratio.

8352ebd3-26f0-4540-9d95-d4670628a89a.label: Defining Initial Term
8352ebd3-26f0-4540-9d95-d4670628a89a.description: Recursive formulas require an initial term (a_1) to start the sequence. This is the first number in the sequence.

51a44965-fb69-4edc-b3d1-49b34428628b.label: Applying Recursive Formula
51a44965-fb69-4edc-b3d1-49b34428628b.description: To find subsequent terms, multiply the common ratio with the previous term defined by recursive formula.

8d7ba75f-ef20-44c7-a647-3a7f97730b0d.label: Recursive Formula for Geometric
8d7ba75f-ef20-44c7-a647-3a7f97730b0d.description: A recursive formula defines each term based on the previous term and the common ratio: a_n = r * a_(n-1).

aa5be5bc-cb2f-4fd8-a839-d992a94c9d55.label: Using Explicit Formula
aa5be5bc-cb2f-4fd8-a839-d992a94c9d55.description: To find a specific term, substitute the term number 'n' into the explicit formula.

a0a98f14-7cd7-4c15-8280-ff195af4827d.label: Explicit Formula for Geometric
a0a98f14-7cd7-4c15-8280-ff195af4827d.description: An explicit formula defines each term based on its position (n) in the sequence: a_n = a_1 * r^(n-1).

526074b1-1d94-4bac-9ffb-e53872defa15.label: Understanding Geometric Sequences
526074b1-1d94-4bac-9ffb-e53872defa15.description: Defines geometric sequences, common ratio, recursive and explicit formulas. Focuses on identifying and generating geometric sequences.

ec312ffc-589c-4068-8099-3aaeddf3c772.label: Index of Summation
ec312ffc-589c-4068-8099-3aaeddf3c772.description: The index of summation is the variable used in the explicit formula within the summation.

8894fe43-ec1f-46e9-a6bd-cfc2a3c78745.label: Lower and Upper Limits
8894fe43-ec1f-46e9-a6bd-cfc2a3c78745.description: Lower limit is the starting value for the index; upper limit is the ending value. Defines the range of summation.

53ae07ed-d0a2-4ed8-931f-709c60d8de51.label: Summation Notation
53ae07ed-d0a2-4ed8-931f-709c60d8de51.description: Summation notation (Σ) is a concise way to represent the sum of a series. Includes index, lower limit, and upper limit.

563a7206-d87f-46f5-b7e6-03ef588fe7ef.label: Identifying First and Last Term
563a7206-d87f-46f5-b7e6-03ef588fe7ef.description: The first term (a_1) and last term (a_n) are needed to calculate the sum of an arithmetic series.

d34a9510-697e-4521-9e54-c5f5818be208.label: Determining Number of Terms
d34a9510-697e-4521-9e54-c5f5818be208.description: The number of terms 'n' in the series is also required for the sum calculation.

c9d0ebcb-24f7-4f9d-8557-9926ea164441.label: Arithmetic Series Sum
c9d0ebcb-24f7-4f9d-8557-9926ea164441.description: The sum of the first 'n' terms of an arithmetic series is S_n = n/2 * (a_1 + a_n), where a_1 is the first term and a_n is the nth term.

6b529874-5dc7-4510-a51e-9ce0f6bcdda7.label: Identifying Common Ratio
6b529874-5dc7-4510-a51e-9ce0f6bcdda7.description: The common ratio 'r' is needed to calculate the sum of a geometric series.

8c143c93-4519-4212-aaf7-5eabf7346d1b.label: Applying Sum Formula
8c143c93-4519-4212-aaf7-5eabf7346d1b.description: Substitute a_1, r, and n into the geometric series sum formula to find the sum.

42985202-e35c-407c-9d8a-c8c339f1c6ae.label: Geometric Series Sum
42985202-e35c-407c-9d8a-c8c339f1c6ae.description: The sum of the first 'n' terms of a geometric series is S_n = a_1 * (1 - r^n) / (1 - r), where a_1 is the first term and r is the common ratio.

cfb4756c-409a-44a8-9832-f453a6a3ae97.label: Condition for Convergence
cfb4756c-409a-44a8-9832-f453a6a3ae97.description: The common ratio 'r' must have an absolute value less than 1 for the infinite series to converge.

47f4f78e-c3f4-4e5c-90cd-5702f5c9b94d.label: Applying Infinite Sum Formula
47f4f78e-c3f4-4e5c-90cd-5702f5c9b94d.description: If the series converges, substitute a_1 and r into the formula S = a_1 / (1 - r) to find the sum.

de659718-e4fd-4acf-8514-bb8ae7f9c1d0.label: Infinite Geometric Series Sum
de659718-e4fd-4acf-8514-bb8ae7f9c1d0.description: The sum of an infinite geometric series exists if |r| < 1, and is S = a_1 / (1 - r).

c0820526-a35b-4490-b52c-2867bfb18082.label: Calculating Future Value
c0820526-a35b-4490-b52c-2867bfb18082.description: The future value depends on the deposit amount, interest rate, compounding frequency, and number of deposits.

ff03e67f-2d6f-4ba0-b675-79649c3f36e3.label: Using Geometric Series Formula
ff03e67f-2d6f-4ba0-b675-79649c3f36e3.description: The future value can be calculated using the geometric series formula adjusted for annuity parameters.
examples: Applying formula for monthly compounded interest

2eeca590-0df3-4924-a21a-834c6c752d5b.label: Annuity Problems
2eeca590-0df3-4924-a21a-834c6c752d5b.description: An annuity is a series of regular payments. The future value is calculated using a geometric series formula.
examples: Monthly deposits into a retirement fund
Annual investments into a college fund

3268bf56-c1b8-4a8a-b20d-9b3f85a4aca7.label: Series and Summation Notation
3268bf56-c1b8-4a8a-b20d-9b3f85a4aca7.description: Covers summation notation, arithmetic series, geometric series, infinite geometric series, and annuity problems.

9794d1ac-c1b0-4eac-b74e-082cec40573b.label: Identifying Non-Overlapping Events
9794d1ac-c1b0-4eac-b74e-082cec40573b.description: Events must be mutually exclusive to apply the addition principle. No shared outcomes.
examples: Choosing a red card or a black card
Choosing a prime number or a composite number

186725b4-7b03-4f6b-9fd0-4bc2823a64d7.label: Addition Principle
186725b4-7b03-4f6b-9fd0-4bc2823a64d7.description: If one event can occur in m ways and another in n ways (with no overlap), then either event can occur in m + n ways.
examples: Choosing a color from 3 green or 4 blue
Selecting a book from 5 novels or 3 biographies

0fb74bf2-b676-4acf-9daf-c73cea636d34.label: Independent Events
0fb74bf2-b676-4acf-9daf-c73cea636d34.description: The outcome of one event does not affect the outcome of the other for multiplication principle to apply.
examples: Rolling a die and flipping a coin

c53e0fe1-8797-4c6b-bc2c-b630872b03a0.label: Multiplication Principle
c53e0fe1-8797-4c6b-bc2c-b630872b03a0.description: If one event can occur in m ways and another in n ways, then the two events can occur together in m * n ways.
examples: Choosing an appetizer and an entree
Creating a password with letters and numbers

21b7dea9-0ce7-4b8d-80b0-311b945d4553.label: Distinct Objects Permutations
21b7dea9-0ce7-4b8d-80b0-311b945d4553.description: Permutations of 'n' distinct objects taken 'r' at a time. No repetition allowed.
examples: Arranging 5 books from 8 on a shelf

3b659612-d7ae-4b66-9475-183d2d7bce89.label: Formula Application
3b659612-d7ae-4b66-9475-183d2d7bce89.description: Applying the permutation formula to calculate the number of arrangements.

40088403-5038-41e0-8649-e415bb4caaf3.label: Permutations: Order Matters
40088403-5038-41e0-8649-e415bb4caaf3.description: A permutation is an arrangement of objects where order is important. Formula: P(n,r) = n! / (n-r)!

f8e93eb4-b952-4613-ba41-a721426cea39.label: Distinct Objects Combinations
f8e93eb4-b952-4613-ba41-a721426cea39.description: Combinations of 'n' distinct objects taken 'r' at a time. Order is irrelevant.
examples: Choosing 3 toppings from 10 for a pizza

6fac9e28-f934-4ee5-8272-064f8b1919c5.label: Formula Application
6fac9e28-f934-4ee5-8272-064f8b1919c5.description: Applying the combination formula to calculate the number of selections.

9c667743-775f-49ea-83df-02cb951acc44.label: Combinations: Order Doesn't Matter
9c667743-775f-49ea-83df-02cb951acc44.description: A combination is a selection of objects where order is not important. Formula: C(n,r) = n! / (r! * (n-r)!).
examples: Choosing a committee from a group

5ae0a72c-1d29-470e-a98c-c7e74bb7000c.label: Identifying Repeated Objects
5ae0a72c-1d29-470e-a98c-c7e74bb7000c.description: Count the number of times each object is repeated in the arrangement.

a30de959-5b89-4753-96c9-f1a8fcda9edc.label: Applying Non-Distinct Formula
a30de959-5b89-4753-96c9-f1a8fcda9edc.description: Using the formula to adjust for overcounting due to repeated objects.

8ffe29fa-b1fa-4255-bd55-82b8d280a38f.label: Non-Distinct Objects Permutations
8ffe29fa-b1fa-4255-bd55-82b8d280a38f.description: If there are n elements and n1 are alike, n2 are alike, etc, permutations are found by n! / (n1! * n2! * ...).
examples: Arranging colored balls in a row

1cff74b0-8a30-452e-88f4-d0d2b0ced20c.label: Understanding Subsets
1cff74b0-8a30-452e-88f4-d0d2b0ced20c.description: A subset is a set formed from elements of a larger set. Elements can be picked or not.

d01aba7d-8bbb-497d-b25b-e3655b6a00dd.label: Applying Power of 2
d01aba7d-8bbb-497d-b25b-e3655b6a00dd.description: Each element has two choices: be in the subset or not.  Therefore, 2 options for each element.

7267f36c-1514-417f-b0bd-a9f8bbfb0666.label: Number of Subsets
7267f36c-1514-417f-b0bd-a9f8bbfb0666.description: A set with n distinct objects has 2^n subsets (including the empty set and the set itself).
examples: A set with 3 elements has 2^3 = 8 subsets
A set with 5 elements has 2^5 = 32 subsets

53e4a419-b3fd-4cab-ab4a-c5bd3b2141ef.label: Counting Principles: Permutations and Combinations
53e4a419-b3fd-4cab-ab4a-c5bd3b2141ef.description: Covers addition and multiplication principles, permutations, combinations, and non-distinct objects counting.
examples: Selecting a committee from a group

632afe6b-2f86-468d-a602-f07c3ff2a349.label: Binomial Coefficients
632afe6b-2f86-468d-a602-f07c3ff2a349.description: The binomial coefficient (n choose k) represents the number of ways to choose k items from n, order irrelevant.

3de370eb-bd54-430d-a0d6-cea3ed7be36c.label: Expansion Formula
3de370eb-bd54-430d-a0d6-cea3ed7be36c.description: (a + b)^n = Σ (n choose k) * a^(n-k) * b^k, from k=0 to n

0c47a87f-ae83-472d-86ee-226a96aeebd5.label: Binomial Expansion
0c47a87f-ae83-472d-86ee-226a96aeebd5.description: The binomial theorem provides a formula to expand (a + b)^n using binomial coefficients.

222e619a-4434-4766-9707-5ab3e127177c.label: Applying Term Formula
222e619a-4434-4766-9707-5ab3e127177c.description: Substitute values into the formula to calculate the coefficient and variables of the specific term.

909a4e0f-ae10-4859-add1-d113af2f6090.label: Finding a Specific Term
909a4e0f-ae10-4859-add1-d113af2f6090.description: Formula to find a specific term (r+1) in a binomial expansion: (n choose r) * a^(n-r) * b^r.

8904d72c-7c89-4d99-a351-3cf79d6b1bd9.label: Binomial Theorem
8904d72c-7c89-4d99-a351-3cf79d6b1bd9.description: Deals with binomial coefficients, binomial expansion, and finding specific terms of a binomial expansion.

315c4b97-fd8d-45d1-8fbf-acbd76b1e0fa.label: Equally Likely Outcomes
315c4b97-fd8d-45d1-8fbf-acbd76b1e0fa.description: When all outcomes are equally likely, probability is the number of favorable outcomes divided by the total number of outcomes.
examples: Probability of rolling a 4 on a fair die: 1/6
Probability of drawing an ace from a deck: 4/52

1eb63cb6-11b8-4971-a498-b03927b4dff0.label: Probability Models
1eb63cb6-11b8-4971-a498-b03927b4dff0.description: A probability model lists all possible outcomes of an experiment and their associated probabilities. Probabilities sum to 1.
examples: Rolling a fair die: each outcome has probability 1/6
Tossing a fair coin: H (0.5), T (0.5)

977c6954-3118-4248-981a-f2d8ad589a9b.label: Mutually Exclusive Events
977c6954-3118-4248-981a-f2d8ad589a9b.description: If events A and B are mutually exclusive (no overlap), then P(A U B) = P(A) + P(B).
examples: Probability of drawing a heart or a spade
Probability of rolling a 1 or a 2

51bc789e-882c-4fca-90d3-f1548a2b28da.label: Intersection of Events
51bc789e-882c-4fca-90d3-f1548a2b28da.description: P(A ∩ B) represents the probability of both events A and B occurring simultaneously.
examples: Probability of drawing a heart and a 7
Probability of rolling an even number and a number less than 4

b50369d4-9296-4814-85d7-1456b1e89b04.label: Union of Events
b50369d4-9296-4814-85d7-1456b1e89b04.description: The probability of event A or event B is P(A U B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B).
examples: Probability of drawing a heart or a king
Probability of rolling an even number or a number greater than 3

bf866218-9ecc-4496-9337-b487c8d7b3e5.label: Applying Complement
bf866218-9ecc-4496-9337-b487c8d7b3e5.description: Useful when calculating the probability of 'at least' or 'no more than' scenarios.
examples: Probability of at least one head in 3 coin tosses
Probability of no more than 2 tails in 4 coin tosses

d2a545eb-a363-44d6-a75d-0b4a75ce9b63.label: Complement Rule
d2a545eb-a363-44d6-a75d-0b4a75ce9b63.description: The probability of an event not occurring is P(A') = 1 - P(A).
examples: Probability of not drawing an ace

b608eaad-e016-4eb8-94b8-30fecc331e3a.label: Using Permutations
b608eaad-e016-4eb8-94b8-30fecc331e3a.description: When order matters, use permutations to calculate the number of favorable outcomes and total outcomes.
examples: Probability of winning a race trifecta
Probability of arranging letters in a specific order

c757fc7b-fac3-4023-a31f-520583278a9f.label: Using Combinations
c757fc7b-fac3-4023-a31f-520583278a9f.description: When order doesn't matter, use combinations to calculate the number of favorable outcomes and total outcomes.
examples: Probability of selecting a certain hand of cards

784d22ce-950f-4b84-a7af-c08425083059.label: Probability and Counting Theory
784d22ce-950f-4b84-a7af-c08425083059.description: Using permutations and combinations to calculate probabilities in complex scenarios.
examples: Probability of selecting a specific committee
Probability of arranging cards in a certain order

408d374f-2ce4-4d11-b729-95d58c5bf788.label: Probability: Events and Outcomes
408d374f-2ce4-4d11-b729-95d58c5bf788.description: Deals with probability models, calculating probabilities of equally likely outcomes, unions, complements, and using counting theory.
examples: Drawing a card from a deck

e00b1ad0-5ef6-4178-b986-cc813bded6fd.label: Arithmetic Sequences and Series
e00b1ad0-5ef6-4178-b986-cc813bded6fd.description: Covers arithmetic sequences, their formulas, and how to find sums of arithmetic and geometric series. Includes applications and problem-solving techniques.
examples: Finding the nth term of a sequence
Calculating the sum of an arithmetic series

1e0400a5-e9ad-442d-a5e9-db8bbe10211f.label: Derivative Test for Monotonicity
1e0400a5-e9ad-442d-a5e9-db8bbe10211f.description: Using the sign of the first derivative to determine if a function is increasing (f'(x) > 0) or decreasing (f'(x) < 0).
examples: If f'(x) = 2x, then f(x) is increasing for x > 0
f'(x) = -x, then f(x) is decreasing for x > 0

e980942e-8487-4926-b704-ad5b9e8d6f18.label: Graphical Identification
e980942e-8487-4926-b704-ad5b9e8d6f18.description: Visually identifying increasing and decreasing intervals by observing the direction of the graph's slope.
examples: A graph rising from left to right indicates increasing
A graph falling from left to right indicates decreasing

2315b42a-bdb2-4e25-9589-a236f8c50a5d.label: Increasing and Decreasing Intervals
2315b42a-bdb2-4e25-9589-a236f8c50a5d.description: Identifying intervals where a function's value is either consistently increasing or decreasing, using derivative analysis or graph observation.

cd2b393d-115c-436a-b9dc-b5d6fdd365b4.label: First Derivative Test for Extrema
cd2b393d-115c-436a-b9dc-b5d6fdd365b4.description: Using the first derivative to find critical points and determine if they are local maxima or minima.
examples: f'(c) = 0 and f'' (c) < 0 implies a local maximum
f'(c) = 0 and f''(c) > 0 implies a local minimum

c20bd82b-05fb-44e9-b856-edba497a6211.label: Graphical Identification of Extrema
c20bd82b-05fb-44e9-b856-edba497a6211.description: Visually identifying local maxima as peaks and local minima as valleys on the graph.
examples: A peak on the graph represents a local maximum
A valley on the graph represents a local minimum

f4956099-97b2-4dae-a4c8-b54ef80b7578.label: Local Extrema: Maxima and Minima
f4956099-97b2-4dae-a4c8-b54ef80b7578.description: Locating points on a graph where the function achieves a local maximum or minimum value within a specific interval.
examples: Local maximum: f(c) ≥ f(x) for x near c
Local minimum: f(c) ≤ f(x) for x near c

153e1c52-10f2-40e8-a609-87f88c9b6883.label: Calculation of Average Rate
153e1c52-10f2-40e8-a609-87f88c9b6883.description: Applying the formula (f(b) - f(a)) / (b - a) to determine the average rate of change between two points.
examples: If f(x) = x² from x=1 to x=3, average rate = (9-1)/(3-1) = 4
Finding average speed over a time interval

54525287-3763-4779-b8f9-4adf2ab83911.label: Interpretation of Average Rate
54525287-3763-4779-b8f9-4adf2ab83911.description: Understanding the average rate of change as the constant rate that would produce the same total change over the interval.
examples: The average population growth per year
The average temperature change per hour

426cc56d-1bb6-46b0-bb0f-83eacaf4f363.label: Average Rate of Change
426cc56d-1bb6-46b0-bb0f-83eacaf4f363.description: Calculating the average rate at which a function's value changes over a specified interval, representing the slope of the secant line.
examples: Average rate of change = (f(b) - f(a)) / (b - a)
Example: change in population per year

2d9b4f1e-4a46-4c9c-a0ee-decd3673c92a.label: Rates of Change and Graph Behavior
2d9b4f1e-4a46-4c9c-a0ee-decd3673c92a.description: Analysis of how functions change over intervals, including increasing/decreasing intervals, local extrema, and average rates of change to describe graph behavior.

7ff83233-88b8-4b46-8b2b-6d2f6c31ec26.label: Evaluating Composite Functions
7ff83233-88b8-4b46-8b2b-6d2f6c31ec26.description: Calculating the output of a composite function for a given input value.
examples: If f(x) = x² and g(x) = 2, then f(g(2)) = f(2) = 4
Finding the total cost after tax and shipping

f664ec4e-3b65-4589-8c61-91d4b40c451a.label: Domain of Composite Functions
f664ec4e-3b65-4589-8c61-91d4b40c451a.description: Determining the set of input values for which the composite function is defined, considering restrictions of both inner and outer functions.
examples: The domain of f(g(x)) is restricted by the domain of g(x) and f(x)
Considering square roots and division by zero

84714709-660a-4aad-97f7-302d34973401.label: Composition of Functions
84714709-660a-4aad-97f7-302d34973401.description: Combining two functions by applying one function to the result of another, denoted as (f ∘ g)(x) = f(g(x)).
examples: If f(x) = x² and g(x) = x + 1, then f(g(x)) = (x + 1)²
Applying a discount after calculating sales tax

cbd4d76b-4c7f-4128-a710-09aca135cbce.label: Finding Inverse Functions Algebraically
cbd4d76b-4c7f-4128-a710-09aca135cbce.description: Switching x and y in the original function and solving for y to find the inverse function.
examples: If y = 3x + 1, then x = 3y + 1, so y = (x - 1)/3
Finding the inverse of a linear equation

53558704-639d-4087-8e67-cb4706157e80.label: Domain and Range of Inverse Functions
53558704-639d-4087-8e67-cb4706157e80.description: The domain of f⁻¹(x) is the range of f(x), and the range of f⁻¹(x) is the domain of f(x).
examples: If f(x) has domain [0, ∞) and range [0, ∞), then f⁻¹(x) has domain [0, ∞) and range [0, ∞)
Inverting a logarithmic function to an exponential

54d57e96-cee5-4255-96eb-20a59278efa2.label: Inverse Functions
54d57e96-cee5-4255-96eb-20a59278efa2.description: Finding a function that reverses the effect of another function, denoted as f⁻¹(x), such that f⁻¹(f(x)) = x.
examples: Converting Celsius to Fahrenheit and back

0b611b60-a723-4254-ab45-0cb816ab7fd1.label: Horizontal Line Test
0b611b60-a723-4254-ab45-0cb816ab7fd1.description: Using the horizontal line test to determine if a function is one-to-one by checking if any horizontal line intersects the graph more than once.
examples: If a horizontal line intersects the graph once, it is one-to-one
If a horizontal line intersects the graph multiple times, it is not one-to-one

ef8f6391-fdb5-4141-b8c2-a526a7608030.label: Restricting the Domain
ef8f6391-fdb5-4141-b8c2-a526a7608030.description: Limiting the domain of a non-one-to-one function to create a one-to-one function and allow for an inverse.
examples: Restricting f(x) = x² to x ≥ 0 makes it one-to-one
Finding the inverse of a trigonometric function

da5bfd8d-88fd-43aa-ba64-03ffe76ee20f.label: One-to-One Functions
da5bfd8d-88fd-43aa-ba64-03ffe76ee20f.description: A function where each output corresponds to exactly one input, allowing for the existence of a unique inverse.
examples: f(x) = x² is not one-to-one over the real numbers

9785e57d-9c80-4bcf-b954-54b4cf5b39c6.label: Composition and Inverse Functions
9785e57d-9c80-4bcf-b954-54b4cf5b39c6.description: Understanding how to combine functions and find inverses, including domain and range considerations and determining one-to-one properties.

80bf76fc-6c0c-4478-9220-9f218ed9fd62.label: Horizontal and Vertical Shifts
80bf76fc-6c0c-4478-9220-9f218ed9fd62.description: Moving the graph of a function left or right (horizontal) or up or down (vertical).
examples: f(x - h): horizontal shift by h units
f(x) + k: vertical shift by k units

d4932877-1574-41b3-8ee6-d9c2d4188b93.label: Reflections about Axes
d4932877-1574-41b3-8ee6-d9c2d4188b93.description: Flipping the graph of a function over the x-axis (vertical reflection) or the y-axis (horizontal reflection).

86a06f1f-2cd9-40ee-94dc-58c883dc7495.label: Stretches and Compressions
86a06f1f-2cd9-40ee-94dc-58c883dc7495.description: Changing the size of the graph by stretching or compressing it horizontally or vertically.
examples: a * f(x): vertical stretch/compression by a factor of a
f(bx): horizontal stretch/compression by a factor of 1/b

65d4a2d3-ca79-4bf4-8365-a33c952261cb.label: Shifts, Reflections, Stretches, and Compressions
65d4a2d3-ca79-4bf4-8365-a33c952261cb.description: Understanding and applying various transformations to functions, including horizontal and vertical shifts, reflections about axes, and stretches/compressions.

d9868d1b-0520-4e7a-9d0b-505dfa9cc912.label: Graphing Absolute Value Functions
d9868d1b-0520-4e7a-9d0b-505dfa9cc912.description: Creating the graph of an absolute value function by reflecting the portion of the graph below the x-axis above the x-axis.

9f3aba61-9ca9-4d75-8870-77bd4af9d45c.label: Solving Absolute Value Equations and Inequalities
9f3aba61-9ca9-4d75-8870-77bd4af9d45c.description: Using the properties of absolute value to solve equations and inequalities by considering both positive and negative cases.
examples: |x| = a implies x = a or x = -a

333f9991-2e8b-4b51-8ad1-359d30828a6c.label: Absolute Value Functions
333f9991-2e8b-4b51-8ad1-359d30828a6c.description: Functions that return the non-negative value of an expression, resulting in graphs with sharp corners and symmetry.

0126b773-ba02-4595-a855-b5fca53955c0.label: Transformations and Absolute Value Functions
0126b773-ba02-4595-a855-b5fca53955c0.description: Applying transformations (shifts, reflections, stretches, compressions) to functions, and analyzing absolute value functions, their graphs, and equations.

d19efbc9-9351-4960-9e17-f12c1880ed03.label: Relations and Functions
d19efbc9-9351-4960-9e17-f12c1880ed03.description: Distinguishing between relations (sets of ordered pairs) and functions (relations with unique outputs for each input).

458a2d55-3143-469c-9e38-1aad20b6c7c2.label: Domain and Range
458a2d55-3143-469c-9e38-1aad20b6c7c2.description: Identifying the set of all possible input values (domain) and the set of all possible output values (range) for a function.

9eb2aec5-89f4-4394-a135-6d0610f09ba4.label: Vertical Line Test
9eb2aec5-89f4-4394-a135-6d0610f09ba4.description: Using the vertical line test to determine if a graph represents a function by checking if any vertical line intersects the graph more than once.
examples: If a vertical line intersects the graph once, it is a function
If a vertical line intersects the graph multiple times, it is not a function

e51df984-d949-45be-9279-0126c26db0a8.label: Foundational Function Concepts
e51df984-d949-45be-9279-0126c26db0a8.description: Review of basic function concepts including relations, functions, domain, range, and function identification using graphical tests.
examples: Vertical line test: only one y-value for each x-value
Domain restrictions: square roots of negatives

421fd7ba-a8a4-4ade-b562-cdaf8ad2f387.label: Transformations of Functions and Advanced Concepts
421fd7ba-a8a4-4ade-b562-cdaf8ad2f387.description: Comprehensive review of function transformations including shifts, reflections, stretches, and compressions, along with advanced topics like composition, absolute value, inverses, rates of change, and graphs.

f70a2400-d998-4304-9fb3-6fc2d5f7ae40.label: Transformations of Functions: Shifts, Reflections, Stretches, Compressions

content_analysis.main_topic: Transformations of Functions: Shifts, Reflections, Stretches, Compressions
